rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 bread . . . water. The chaotic conditions result in lack of food and water. See note 1:30.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:2–3
rsbNotes.text: 3:2, 3 mighty man . . . expert in charms. The Lord will remove every kind of leader that the people were trusting to secure their society: warriors, sages, magicians, and other prominent people. See 11:2 note.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:4
rsbNotes.text: 3:4 boys . . . infants. The nation will be ruled by people without experience and unable to govern wisely.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 every one his neighbor. The collapse of civilization comes with social strife: rich against poor, young against old.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:6
rsbNotes.text: 3:6 cloak. In a collapsing society, someone who has as little as a decent suit of clothes will seem prosperous enough to be made a ruler. But when the people try to draft such a person, he will reply that his wealth is only an illusion; he has no better answers than they have.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:8
rsbNotes.text: 3:8 Jerusalem . . . Judah. The fall of Jerusalem (586 b.c.) was a partial fulfillment of this prophecy, as was the devastation caused by Sennacherib’s siege of the city in 701 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:9
rsbNotes.text: 3:9 Sodom. Israel has no sense of shame, defying God and acting as if the covenant did not exist. See 1:9, 10.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:12
rsbNotes.text: 3:12 O my people. See note 40:1. On the lack of leadership and its consequences, see 3:4–7 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:15
rsbNotes.text: 3:15 crushing my people. Compare the actions of these rulers with those of the ideal Davidic king in 11:3–5.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:16
rsbNotes.text: 3:16 daughters of Zion. They live to the fullest at the expense of others. The ornaments are meant to impress others, to provide cash in case of an emergency, and to supply magical protection from sudden disaster. This outward adornment reflects an inner attitude of pride (1 Pet. 3:3, 4).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:24–4:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:24–4:1 rottenness . . . reproach. The destitution threatened by the day of the Lord is expressed with words associated with bloodshed, war, and captivity.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 3:26
rsbNotes.text: 3:26 gates. Jerusalem is personified and joins in the lament.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 in that day. See note 2:11.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:2
rsbNotes.text:
4:2 branch. The term has two possible senses: one is literal, corresponding to the parallel phrase “fruit of the land,” and the other is as a messianic title for Jesus Christ, who yields spiritual fruit (11:1–5; Jer. 23:5; Zech. 3:8; John 15:1–8). The remnant find life in Him (6:13). Because Jesus humbled Himself, He is crowned with glory (52:13; 53:12; Phil. 2:9–11).

glorious. This means displaying the splendor and brightness of God. The glory of God is revealed in all His works, but especially in the Messiah (Ps. 19:1; John 1:18).

the survivors. That is, a remnant (1:9 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:3
rsbNotes.text:
4:3 Zion. See note 1:8.

holy. Consecrated to God, the Holy One of Israel (1:4 note; 62:12).

recorded. Their names are written in the “book” of life (Ex. 32:32, 33; Ps. 69:28; Dan. 12:1; Rev. 20:12).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:4
rsbNotes.text:
4:4 spirit. Possibly this is the Holy Spirit, but more likely it refers to the process of purification (cf. 28:6).

burning. This metaphor signifies judgment (1:31; 10:17; 30:27; 42:25). Through the process of refining fire, consuming the faithless and purifying the faithful, God will produce a holy Zion.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:5
rsbNotes.text:
4:5 create. In the new act of redemption, the Creator of heaven and earth (40:26; 42:5; 45:12, 18) will renew everything for the sake of His people. The glory of the messianic age is given by God, and does not come from human effort or skill (Jon. 2:9; Eph. 2:4–10).

cloud . . . smoke . . . shining of a flaming fire. Unlike the burning of the fire of judgment in v. 4, this cloud and fire signals God’s protective presence, as at the Red Sea (Ex. 13:20–22), over the tabernacle (Ex. 40:34–38), and in the wilderness (Num. 9:15–23). Here His presence covers a restored and sanctified Mount Zion (2:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 4:6
rsbNotes.text:
4:6 shade. See note 30:2.

refuge. In contrast to human deceptions (28:15, 17), the Lord provides effective shelter from the storm (25:4; cf. Ps. 14:6; 46:1; 62:7; 94:22).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:1–7
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–7 The owner and the vineyard stand for God and His people. The song is fulfilled in Jesus Christ, who replaces sour grapes with new fruit (Matt. 21:33–44; John 15:1–6).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:2
rsbNotes.text:
5:2 watchtower . . . grapes. These images reinforce the expectation of an abundant harvest.

wild grapes. The Hebrew means “stinking things.”

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:5
rsbNotes.text: 5:5 devoured . . . trampled. God decrees desolation.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:6
rsbNotes.text: 5:6 briers and thorns. The weeds represent God’s curse (7:23–25; 32:13), that is, the anarchy following war (3:4, 5). God can also turn curse into blessing, replacing the briers and thorns with the pine tree and myrtle (55:13).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:7
rsbNotes.text: 5:7 Lord of hosts. See note 1:9.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:8
rsbNotes.text:
5:8 This is the first of six exclamations of woe, proclaiming God’s displeasure on greed, drunkenness, and other sins. The first woe condemns greed.

add field to field. The land belonged to God (Lev. 25:23), had been allotted to specific families by patrimony (Num. 33:54), and was the basis of livelihood. Deprived of their land, small farmers in Israel became day laborers or slaves.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:9
rsbNotes.text: 5:9 houses. God’s judgment targets the rich in their self-indulgence. Mansions provide no protection from his eye (24:10 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 bath . . . homer . . . ephah. The bath was a liquid measure of about six gallons. For its size, the vineyard would produce practically nothing. Likewise, a homer of seed planted would yield only an ephah of produce. Six bushels of seed would yield about a half bushel at harvest. The land would be cursed (Deut. 28:38, 39).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:11
rsbNotes.text: 5:11 wine. The second woe condemns drunkenness. See note 24:11. Overindulgence in drink is a characteristic of social corruption and moral laxity (chs. 22, 28; Amos 4:1–3; 6:6, 7).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:13
rsbNotes.text:
5:13 my people. See note 40:1.

exile. The exile with all its miseries is threatened as a judgment on the people, who have shown no knowledge of the right way to behave.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:14
rsbNotes.text: 5:14 Sheol. This is the Hebrew word for “the grave,” used almost exclusively in poetry. See Prov. 9:18 and notes. Isaiah portrays death as a terrible beast that devours anyone without regard to social class, both the “honored” and the “multitude” (v. 13).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:16
rsbNotes.text: 5:16 righteousness. See 1:21 note.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:18
rsbNotes.text: 5:18 The third woe condemns those who mock God as they sin.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:19
rsbNotes.text: 5:19 the Holy One of Israel. See 1:4 note.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:20
rsbNotes.text:
5:20 The fourth woe condemns moral corruption.

darkness . . . light. See notes 2:5 and 5:30.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:21
rsbNotes.text:
5:21 The fifth woe condemns pride and self-righteousness.

wise in their own eyes. This is an expression for irrational, arrogant autonomy. A revelation from God, who alone knows all things, is the only firm foundation for knowledge.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:22
rsbNotes.text:
5:22 The sixth woe condemns those who pervert justice.

mixing strong drink. This refers to wine and beer with spices added. Once again, as in 5:11, Isaiah speaks of overindulgence.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:23
rsbNotes.text: 5:23 bribe. See note 1:23. Bribery involves injustice and greed, as in 5:8.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:24
rsbNotes.text: 5:24 fire. See note on “burning” at 4:4.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:25
rsbNotes.text:
5:25 the mountains quaked. At the revelation of God’s anger, nature quakes (2:19; 13:13; 24:18, 19; Ezek. 32:6–8 note). For a contrasting image of redemption, see 54:10.

streets. See note 24:11.

his anger has not turned away. God is not reconciled, and His wrath hangs over the disobedient (9:12, 17, 21; 10:4; 31:3).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:26–30
rsbNotes.text: 5:26–30 This description of the Assyrian army closely matches its portrayal on ancient Assyrian reliefs; perhaps the poet had seen such troops with his own eyes.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:26
rsbNotes.text:
5:26 signal. This is a signal flag (11:10, 12; 18:3; 49:22; 62:10). Like a commander in battle, the Lord summons the nations to execute His judgment (10:5).

nations afar off. These would be Syria, Assyria, Babylon, etc. The imperial Assyrian army was composed of mercenaries hired from all over the Assyrian Empire.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 5:30
rsbNotes.text:
5:30 on that day. See note 2:11.

darkness. This metaphor for depression, alienation, and judgment (8:22; 42:7; 47:5; 60:2) teaches that all who twist justice by living in darkness (5:20; 29:15) will suffer the darkness of God’s judgment. By contrast, the light of God will dawn on the needy (9:2; 29:18; 42:7; 49:9; 58:10; 60:1, 2). The Lord is sovereign over darkness and light (45:7).

distress. The Hebrew word means “sorrow,” “narrowness.” God delivers His own from such confinement (25:4; 63:9).
